Transcribed 6.10.92. To be proof read.
See also H. Read to M, 15 May 1868.
For a published version of this letter see details.
For a copy of the above letter see: Warrnambool examiner, 15 May 1868, p. 4. Bibliography number required.
Melb. bot Garden
The grass, enclosed in your letter of the 24 being destitute of flowers cannot be named.

I will be happy to furnish plants of the maritime Fir, for the Warrnambool town council, as it would be hopeless to raise these pines locally from seeds, unless such seeds were entrusted to a skilled gardener. If an extensive tract was to be sown such should be ploughed and fenced for altho growing in sand this pine could not be raised in sand, which would suffocate the young seedlings. The ploughing might be effected near the drift sand. Be so kind to inform me what area the Council intends to plough or to plant, and also what protection would be afforded against goats, cows and other domestic animals, as well as against the traffic, and whether there are any means of watering the young pines during the hot months of the year.

div.p:
If the grass sent me is a native one, it is likely Festuca litoralis. This might be dug up and planted into localities, on which the sand requires to be arrested, together with couch grass and any other native plant vegetating in sand.
M's letter was read at a Council meeting on 12 May 1868 and referred to the Sand Committee (Borough Council records, minute book 6, p. 451).
